tags.norm:M_highest_priv_mode:
machine-mode (M-mode), which is the highest privilege mode in a RISC-V
hart.
tags.norm:M_mode_at_reset:
M-mode is used for low-level access to a hardware platform and
is the first mode entered at reset.
tags.norm:M_access_all_lower_priv_CSRs: M-mode code can access all CSRs at lower privilege levels.
tags.norm:misa_acc: The misa CSR is a WARL read-write register
tags.norm:misa_always_rd: This register must be readable in any implementation
tags.norm:MISA_CSR_IMPLEMENTED: a value of zero can be returned to indicate the misa register has not been implemented
tags.norm:misa_mxl_op_isa:
The MXL (Machine XLEN) field encodes the native base integer ISA width as
shown in <<misabase>>.
tags.norm:misa_mxl_op_nz:
If misa is nonzero, the
MXL field indicates the effective XLEN in M-mode, a constant termed MXLEN.
tags.norm:misa_sz: The misa CSR is MXLEN bits wide.
tags.norm:misa_extensions_enc:
The Extensions field encodes the presence of the standard extensions,
with a single bit per letter of the alphabet (bit 0 encodes presence of
extension "A" , bit 1 encodes presence of extension "B", through to
bit 25 which encodes "Z").
tags.norm:misa_i_op: The "I" bit will be set for the RV32I and RV64I base ISAs
tags.norm:misa_e_op: the "E" bit will be set for RV32E and RV64E.
tags.norm:misa_extensions_op:
The Extensions field is a WARL field that can contain writable bits where the
implementation allows the supported ISA to be modified.
tags.norm:misa_extensions_rst:
At reset,
the Extensions field shall contain the maximal set of supported extensions,
and "I" shall be selected over "E" if both are available.
tags.norm:misa_extensions_disabling:
When a standard extension is disabled by clearing its bit in misa, the
instructions and CSRs defined or modified by the extension revert to
their defined or reserved behaviors as if the extension is not
implemented.
tags.norm:misa_extensions_impl_def:
For a given RISC-V execution environment, an instruction, extension, or
other feature of the RISC-V ISA is ordinarily judged to be implemented
or not by the observable execution behavior in that environment. For
example, the F extension is said to be implemented for an execution
environment if and only if the instructions that the RISC-V Unprivileged
ISA defines for F execute as specified.
tags.norm:misa_extensions_disabling_def:
With this definition of implemented, disabling an extension by
clearing its bit in misa results in the extension being considered
not implemented in M-mode. For example, setting misa.F=0 results in
the F extension being not implemented for M-mode, because the F
extension’s instructions will not act as the Unprivileged ISA requires
but may instead raise an illegal-instruction exception.
tags.norm:misa_extensions_rsv_ret_0: All bits that are reserved for future use must return zero when read.
tags.norm:misa_x_op: The "X" bit will be set if there are any non-standard extensions.
tags.norm:misa_b_op:
When the "B" bit is 1, the implementation supports the instructions provided by the
Zba, Zbb, and Zbs extensions.
tags.norm:misa_m_op:
When the "M" bit is 1, the implementation supports all multiply and
division instructions defined by the M extension.
tags.norm:Zmmul_misa_m:
if the Zmmul extension is supported then
the multiply instructions it specifies are supported irrespective
of the value of the "M" bit.
tags.norm:misa_s_op: When the "S" bit is 1, the implementation supports supervisor mode.
tags.norm:misa_u_op: When the "U" bit is 1, the implementation supports user mode.
tags.norm:misa_e_not_i:
Unless misa is all read-only zero, the
"E" bit always reads as the complement of the "I" bit.
tags.norm:misa_extensions_dependencies:
If an ISA feature x depends on an ISA feature y, then attempting to
enable feature x but disable feature y results in both features
being disabled.
tags.norm:misa_inc_ialign:
Writing misa may increase IALIGN, e.g., by disabling the "C"
extension. If an instruction that would write misa increases IALIGN,
and the subsequent instruction's address is not IALIGN-bit aligned, the
write to misa is suppressed, leaving misa unchanged.
tags.norm:mvendorid_sz_acc_op:
The mvendorid CSR is a 32-bit read-only register providing the JEDEC
manufacturer ID of the provider of the core.
tags.norm:mvendorid_always_rd:
This register must be readable in any implementation, but a value of 0 can be returned to
indicate the field is not implemented or that this is a non-commercial implementation.
tags.norm:mvendorid_enc:
JEDEC manufacturer IDs are ordinarily encoded as a sequence of one-byte
continuation codes 0x7f, terminated by a one-byte ID not equal to
0x7f, with an odd parity bit in the most-significant bit of each byte.
mvendorid encodes the number of one-byte continuation codes in the
Bank field, and encodes the final byte in the Offset field, discarding
the parity bit.
tags.norm:mvendorid_bank_1_less_than_JEDEC:
In JEDEC’s parlance, the bank number is one greater than the number of
continuation codes; hence, the mvendorid Bank field encodes a value
that is one less than the JEDEC bank number.
tags.norm:marchid_sz_acc_op:
The marchid CSR is an MXLEN-bit read-only register encoding the base
microarchitecture of the hart.
tags.norm:marchid_always_rd:
This register must be readable in any
implementation, but a value of 0 can be returned to indicate the field is not implemented.
tags.norm:mimpid_op:
The mimpid CSR provides a unique encoding of the version of the
processor implementation.
tags.norm:mimpid_always_rd:
This register must be readable in any
implementation, but a value of 0 can be returned to indicate that the field is not implemented.
tags.norm:mhartid_sz_acc_op:
The mhartid CSR is an MXLEN-bit read-only register containing the
integer ID of the hardware thread running the code.
tags.norm:mhartid_always_rd: This register must be readable in any implementation.
tags.norm:mstatus_sz_acc:
The mstatus register is an MXLEN-bit read/write register formatted as
shown in <<mstatusreg-rv32>> for RV32 and <<mstatusreg>> for RV64.
tags.norm:mstatush_sz_acc: For RV32 only, mstatush is a 32-bit read/write register formatted as shown in <<mstatushreg>>.
tags.norm:mstatush_enc: Bits 30:4 of mstatush generally contain the same fields found in bits 62:36 of mstatus for RV64. Fields SD, SXL, and UXL do not exist in mstatush.
